title: 113_hr3357
content:
The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in early childhood education programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "early childhood education program" includes Head Start Programs, State-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschool. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as in the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary of Education can award grants to States for implementing activities described in section 6. Applications for grants can be submitted. Each State seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, including details of their early childhood professional development system developed in collaboration with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. The State must collaborate with various entities to develop its early childhood professional development system, including the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. The State agency responsible for administering the grant program must be designated, and the State's system must have an oversight structure in place. The State's early childhood professional development system must include oversight, professional standards, career advancement opportunities, coordination with higher education institutions, and articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions. Encouragement of articulation agreements between two- and four-year institutions of higher education, credit-bearing opportunities, recognition of prior learning and expertise, accessible higher education for working learners in rural areas, support for adult learners who are dual language learners, low-income, or from minority communities. The curr_chunk focuses on supporting adult learners who are dual language learners, come from low-income or minority communities, using workforce data to assess state workforce needs, and financing over time. The curr_chunk focuses on state use of funds for supporting adult learners from diverse backgrounds and assessing state workforce needs. The State receiving a grant must use funds to provide scholarships for preschool teachers to pursue a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, and to support teachers with a bachelor's degree in another field to obtain credentials or licensure. To increase compensation for teachers enrolled in early childhood education programs and provide professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and assistants. Opportunities for preschool teachers and assistants in early childhood education programs include addressing all areas of child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for working with diverse children and families. Grant funds provided under this Act must supplement, not replace, other federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their financial support for these activities each year. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019 to implement this Act.
